column11: Review Text

column8: We visited the historic Dondra Head Lighthouse
column11: Had a fantastic day touring the southern coast with a lovely family from Germany. We visited the historic Dondra Head Lighthouse, the southernmost point of Sri Lanka, and also witnessed the impressive blow hole nearby. The tour concluded with a drop-off in beautiful Mirissa. A perfect day trip itinerary!

I visited Dondra Point for the first time and it was such a wonderful experience! The place is peaceful and beautifully scenic, with breathtaking ocean views. Standing at the southernmost point of Sri Lanka felt special, and the fresh sea breeze made it even more relaxing. The surroundings are clean and calm, perfect for enjoying nature and taking photos. I‚Äôm really glad I visited ‚Äî it‚Äôs a must-see spot if you‚Äôre in the area!

Sri Lanka‚Äôs southernmost lighthouse, a short walk near the lighthouse, but unable to climb, we were told it had not been visited since the Covid 19 crisis. Too bad because the view must be superb. This all-white lighthouse remains very imposing in this place, push to the creek to the east where local boats are sheltered, the place is peaceful. It would have been built with stones imported from England.
It is one of the best places, I have ever visited, The view is very nice from up there, We can see the whole of Matara, It is an easy climb

column8: Southern Most Point of Sri Lanka. Well maintained & Beautiful.
column11: It's worth visiting this place if you are traveling in the southern part of Sri Lanka. This place is considered as the southern most point of Sri Lanka. Light house and the surrounding are well maintained. Beach is so beautiful too.

column8: Sri Lankan coastal light from the ‚ÄúKnight of Lighthouses‚Äù
column11: Dondra Head Lighthouse was the second lighthouse I visited in Sri Lanka. It is located on the coast of the island, almost at the southernmost tip, in a settlement called Dondra. Some sources write that the lighthouse stands at the southernmost point of Sri Lanka. However, the geographer clarifies: in order to really be in the very, very south of the island, you need to walk 500 meters to the south - that‚Äôs where the very end of Ceylon will be, from where the vastness of the Indian Ocean will open to your eyes all the way to Antarctica!!! But let's return to the goal of our trip - the Dondra Head lighthouse. The latter, with its height of 49 meters, is the tallest lighthouse on the island, as well as one of the tallest lighthouses in Southeast Asia. The Dondra Head Lighthouse owes its appearance to the only British architect who received the title of knight and the title ‚Äúsir‚Äù due to this status for his engineering and ‚Äúlighthouse‚Äù merits - James Nicholas Douglas. The latter was a civil engineer and designer of lighthouses. During his life, Sir James designed at least two dozen famous and not so famous lighthouses in England, Wells, on the islands of Guernsey and Portland, as well as in Sri Lanka. The construction of the Dondra Head Lighthouse began in November 1887, and the construction was led by William Douglas from the Imperial Lighthouse Service (by the way, the brother of the sir mentioned above). Strange as it may sound, ALL the building materials that were used in the construction of this lighthouse were delivered from England!!! Two and a half years later, in March 1890, Dondra Head was put into operation. Like the Barberyn Island Lighthouse I visited earlier, this lighthouse is also one of the island's four international lighthouses. The seven-story faceted ‚Äúbody‚Äù of the Dondra Head lighthouse is cut through in places by window openings. Apparently the very ‚Äúfacetedness‚Äù of the structure made me think about the fortress donjon - the ‚Äútower of last hope‚Äù... Although, as I believe, this is so - for sailors caught in a night storm, the light of the lighthouse is the ray of that very ‚Äúlast hope‚Äù. hope"... Walking with my head up at the foot of the Dondra Head lighthouse, I involuntarily remembered the statement of Andrei Eigus from ‚ÄúTowers of Power‚Äù: ‚ÄúIt seems to me that at the lighthouses themselves you experience something similar to what happens to you in the temple... Some kind of a secret place where there is no one and where you are alone with some magical power...‚Äù Alas, I was not able to climb to the top of this lighthouse - there are stricter rules... However, if fate does take you to the south of Sri Lanka, do not regret a little time - visit Dondra Head Lighthouse. Moreover, this is the only ‚Äúknightly‚Äù lighthouse of the island!!!

Talking Fingers SPA Hiriketiya exceeded all my expectations. The serene atmosphere, coupled with the stunning view, made for a truly magical experience. The staff went above and beyond to ensure my comfort and satisfaction. The massage therapists are truly gifted - I left feeling like a new person.
This historic lighthouse used stone quarried from Cornwall in England' West Country plus Scottish stone. It was modernised in 2000 with GPS. It was worth a 10 minute visit.
Amazing views of the coastline - we were informed that at the moment the lighthouse is only open 2pm-5pm on Saturday afternoons only,but you can wander around it's gardens.
This is one of the landmarked places to visit in sri Lanka, place is well maintained. A very good view of the sea from both ends of the light house
Lovely little spot! The most southern point in Sri Lanka, a cute little post box with a sign explaining. The lighthouse is very pretty, surrounded by bright blue water and lovely picnic spot.

The Dondra Head Lighthouse is far superior in size and location than the Galle lighthouse.  One can drive right up to the parking area, which is only about 100 meters from the lighthouse and walk the rest of the way.  There are generally no crowds, so you can enjoy a much more relaxed time and the views from the area surrounding the lighthouse are also superior to the Galle.  Not sure that I would go out of my way to visit here...but if you're in the area, it's definitely worth a quick look.

Dondra Head Lighthouse is a Lighthouse in Dondra. It is located on Dondra Head, Dondra. Dondra Head Lighthouse has avery beautiful and attractive beach. Sri lanka tallest lighthouse and also one of the tallest in South East Asia. Dondra Head lighthouse is a very beautiful and eye - catching place.

... But as we were passing from Dickwella to Hikkaduwa we got the driver to stop here. 15 minutes is all you need to wonder around and get a few snaps. You can‚Äôt go up the lighthouse but to walk around and right up to it is free.

A nice spot, at the southern most tip of Sri Lanka. The well preserved lighthouse makes for a great photo subject. You can relax and watch the sea crashing in, our sit on the rocks on the opposite side and take in a quiet little cove with local fishermen catch crabs and lagoon prawns.

We, my wife, daughter, and her two kids, visited the octagonal, 49metre tall, white painted Dondra lighthouse tower, on that sunny 23rd December 2019.  Opening times were listed as from 0900 to 1900 hrs.  This 49m high lighthouse is the tallest Sri Lanka.  I was impressed by how impeccably the lighthouse and its premises are "manicured" and maintained by the current lighthouse operator ‚Äì Sri Lanka Ports Authority.  The premises were very clean, neat and attractive giving a charming sense of tranquillity.  It is also located in a very picturesque location surrounded by the blue seas on three sides in the middle of coconut palms.  One of the persons guarding told me that it is still operational.  Though it is advertised as the southernmost point of Sri Lanka, the true southernmost point is "Point Dondra", 300 metres west and 300 metres south of the lighthouse.  Visitors were not permitted to enter the lighthouse tower. One of the 59 fundamental survey benchmarks in Sri Lanka is located within the premises and is protected and out of bounds to visitors.  A bolt on a concrete pillar going down to bedrock marks its position.  Blasting within 100 metres is prohibited for protection of its established reference values. A post-box located within the premises allows visitors to post a letter or a card originating from the southernmost point of Sri Lanka. After spending about an hour at this serene location, we visited the little cove and the bathing spot to the east of the lighthouse where there were many local fishing boats. Very enjoyable visit indeed!

We visited Dondra Head as stop during a day trip around Matara area. It‚Äôs the southernmost point of Sri Lanka, which is marked with a sign - selfie yourself there! And... If you‚Äôre around, go there! Though it‚Äôs unfortunately not possible to enter the Lighthouse. The coast line is beautiful and it has a lagoon with a fantastic picturesque beach to swim.
Just a normal lighthouse. Cannot enter the building. You can walk down to the beach and have your feets dip into the warm waters.

We stopped here in June as one of our party was a retired ship‚Äôs captain and we all found it an interesting place to visit. I enjoyed taking lots of photos as the impressive lighthouse and surrounding palms were quite photogenic. At the entrance was a small stall with refreshingly cold drinks and snacks.

We were told that due to some dodgy ticket sales touts it was not possible to visit the interior of the lighthouse However, on a day when the ocean was particularly angry and waves were crashing on to the surrounding rocks this made for a spectacular visit and photo opportunity

If you have time,  you can sure visit this place though it is nothing like you can't miss considering you can't really climb up and can just visit the surrounding area. Again my request to sri Lankan authorities would be tobput some restrictions on plastic usage,  near the lughthouse,  specially on the backside it is not that clean and well maintained.

Approx 18 Kms from Mirissa Beach Beautiful place to visit,However the place is restricted now for foreign tourist so you will need to get permission to enter premises and also have to get permission  from sri lanka ports authority head office Colombo to go to the top of the lighthouse. The permission will be granted.
Just next to the lighthouse is a lovely juice bar. The guy never heard of TripAdvisor. Surprise him!

If you're in Dondra it's worth spending a little time at the lighthouse. The surroundings are very picturesque and it's only a short walk from the temple with the poorly treated elephant. We got a tuk tuk for 100Rps - and walked back into town, which took about 10 minutes.

This consider as tallest lighthouse and located in southernmost point in Sri Lanka. Currently it operates by Sri Lankan port authority. It has build in 1890 and 160' in height. Sorrounding area is safe to take bath. In order to get real experiance you should climb up, but not recommend for people affraid on height. No recommended dress, but if you planing to climb up use something helpfu for your safety.

We stopped by the lighthouse and were pleasantly surprised how lovely the view was! There is also a little shop at the entrance and a lovely lady let us keep our belongings (surfboard) in the shop while we explored the area. A must see if you‚Äôre around! We were disappointed we didn‚Äôt bring a picnic as there is a little beach too.
The Dondra Head Lighthouse is visible for miles around. A place to admire from a distance rather than visit unless you have time on your hands.
The nicest Srilankans we met were in Dondra. Beautiful setting for a big lighthouse. Shame you can‚Äôt climb it easily anymore (permission needed from harbour master but couldn‚Äôt locate).

Dondra Heads was once the capital of the country and a significant Hindu port town. Prior to its destruction by the invading Portuguese the town boasted over 1000 statues and temples covered with brass, copper and gold. The pillars of the largest temple are spread over the town and can be found by those looking for them, just ask any local as we did and they will point you in the right direction. It does take some looking for though.  It cost Rs 500 just to walk up the tower. It is easy to see why this is the site of Sri Lanka's oldest lighthouse; it commands a majestic & strategic view of the Indian Ocean. Highly recommended for a fascinating visit, set among-st coconut palms & on the edge of huge waves crashing over a craggy outcrop. There is a beautiful view from lighthouse, nice nature around.   For those who wants to photograph, the inside has epic lightning. Though I have to admit the garden and tower was well taken care of. Once you've climbed the entire lighthouse you can see a big part of the island. Wonderful view! Recommended to do so.  It's so worth the climb as views are breathtaking, although you might not be so impressed if you're scared of heights. It's fascinating to see how basic the original lighthouse was; they still have spare panes of 19th century glass in case of breakages in particularly violent weather & the old communication system from top to bottom is hilarious. As this is the south end of Sri Lanka and you can have chance to go up there and see the south pole. It is so nice place and good chance to visit one of the oldest light houses on the earth. It is beautifully kept surroundings, interesting old workings, amazing views of the sea and land, good exercise after lying on Mirissa beach, eating fish, and we saw whales on the radar half way up. It was an easy climb to this the highest lighthouse in Sri Lanka. Definitely worth a visit as the view from top is magnificent. If you have residence visa you can negotiate for a better deal. There are 220 steps each way, my wife counted. You get amazing  360 degree views from the top make the climb worthwhile. Great photo opportunities both at the top and ground level.

Nicely maintained grounds and worth a visit to see the south most point in the island. The lighthouse itself is beautiful. The ocean around it is also nice and relaxing to hang around in the grounds The office area was unmanned and shabby. We went in to see how we can get in. A caretaker came out from under a tree and said we need pre approval from the navy in Colombo or Galle to go up(

While not a "must see" if you have the opportunity to stop on your way across the south, stop in so you can say you were at the southern most tip of Sri Lanka- next stop, Antarctica. For us, our next trip upcoming is actually Antarctica so it doubled the cool factor for us:) We self drove our Tuk Tuk to the lighthouse as we were making our way east along the coast, and finding it was fun because you wiggle thru a small neighborhood of homes to get there. Nothing to pay here, always a plus.

A must visit point along the coast of Sri Lanka but climbing to the top of the lighthouse has a process that needs to be followed where you need to get prior approval from the harbour master. Apart from that it's a very picturesque location

One of the most beautiful lighthouses i have seen in my life. Unfortunately, due to government restrictions, it is not possible to climb it up. Location itself is very quiet and nice. You can swim and snorkel without the crowds at the beach just next to the lighthouse.

The most southerly town in Sri Lanka is Dondra (= City of the Gods). About 1km further south is the splendid Dondra Head Lighthouse, the most southerly point of the country. The lighthouse is land based so that you can touch it, photograph it, walk round it and, if you can obtain the necessary permission, climb the 196 stairs to the top where there is a fine viewing platform. But I understand that permission currently is not granted. It is British by design and construction. Designed by Sir James Nicholas Douglass and built by William Douglass of the British Imperial Lighthouse Service, all the building materials, bricks, steel, granite rock and the Hyper radiant lenses came from Britain. It was first commissioned in 1890. At 49m high it is the tallest lighthouse in Sri Lanka and one of the four international lighthouses in the country. In the year 2000 it was upgraded to include a Global Positioning System and was computer linked to other major lighthouses in the country. It is a very elegant and photogenic structure, octagonal in shape, painted brilliant white and complimented by some coconut palms in a little park. On the site there is a little ice cream stall and parking is adjacent, although very difficult for coaches to manoeuver when turning round. Dondra Head Lighthouse is a great place just to sit for a while, relax and watch the sea crashing against the rocks below. Also, as you look out to sea, you should realise that  the next land mass is noy until you reach Antarctica. Unless you have hired a tuk tuk, locating the lighthouse may depend on asking the locals, for it is poorly signposted from Dondra town.
Beautiful location, unfortunately not possible to climb up there. According to our guide the government closed down the possibility for tourists to enter the lighthouse

I had to visit this lighthouse as I had visited the northernmost point in Sri Lanka near Point Pedro and I had to say I also visited the southernmost point in the island. The views over the ocean are great and the lighthouse is imposing. But you can only walk around it and then leave. There is no information about the lighthouse and nothing to do.
The Southern most lighthouse in Sri Lanka must also be the talles one. It is a nice place and worth passing by and feel the place

Dondra Head is well worth visiting as you will gain the feeling of remoteness, being on the southern-most tip of this beautiful island, with nothing but ocean between you and the Antarctic. Dondra is only a short drive from Matara town and has a pleasant rocky shore where one can walk and enjoy the majestic lighthouse towering above the promontory. The lighthouse itself dates from 1890. I have been to the top of it some years ago but on this visit is was sadly not open, so advisable to check if you wish to climb it.
A beautiful spot to spend an hour and maybe watch the sun go down. Very tranquil after the hustle and bustle of Dondra.

The place is beautiful, very picturesque. There are lots of palm trees in the park around the lighthouse and a nice beach nearby. It's nice to walk around or just sit on a bench in the shadow and relax. Unfortunately, in December 2017 the lighthouse itself was not open for visiting, which was a bit disappointing.

If you are near Mirissa or Matara , Pls don't miss this point... You will have feeling of standing on the tip of world map as beyond this point towards south , its only Antartica... You will be mesmerized with sea sound and color. Yes , its turquoise blue colour . No words No Caption for feeling at point Dondra.

As noted, we could not climb up into the lighthouse. But, it is impressive sight in a wild and beautiful setting. It was built in 1889 on the southern most point in Sri Lanka. Worth a look if you are in the area.

There is basically nothing to do here. You can only see the lighthouse from outside. There was no one there when we went and it was locked, so am unsure if you can actually go inside the lighthouse. The view from the top might be worth seeing if you are allowed to get in. Otherwise don't bother going here.

Southernmost lighthouse in Sri Lanka and considered as the tallest lighthouse in southeast Asia. It is a octagonal elegant building painted in white consists of 7 stories. Built during British Colonial era , started its service in 1890. Now it is among  4 international lighthouses in Sri Lanka. It is situated in Dondra, a famous tourists and pilgrims attraction in southern Lanka, just 6km from Matara. Locals call the area as Devinuwara has meaning of City of Gods. Architecturally superb, robust structure which was built entirely by granite blocks imported from Great Britain. This become world famous by a Hollywood film- Pearls off Dondra Head. You can easily get there. Sign boards are there to guide you. Now you can enter into the lighthouse premises which was initially banned. But you need special permission from Sri Lanka Port Authority to climb  the lighthouse. The entrances is free. You can take photographers there. Open to public on daily basis from 7 am to 5 pm. Parking available for free. The small and the beach is fantastic to enjoy warm tropical sea water. ENJOY THE TRIP!üåÖüåäüåä

It is a very short trip from Matara city to Dondra Lighthouse. It is even visible from Matara city. The lighthouse is very beautiful and majestic. It is really an eye catching sight. The beach (and the rocks) at the lighthouse is also beautiful and very rich in faunal diversity. There are one or two very small natural pools (made by rocks) there. But note that this not a place for swimming. There is a very nearby beach if you want to swim. The only reason I'm giving it only 4 stars, is that the people are not allowed to go inside or up to the top nowadays. Otherwise it will be definitely a 5 star experience.

Visited this majestic lighthouse since our visitors from the USA are very interested in visiting lighthouses. However we were not allowed to go in even after speaking to a gentleman from the ports authority. They settled to admire the beauty from outside which in itself was breath taking. The surrounding beauty. This was captivating scenery all around.

A nice lighthouse, but you are not allowed go to the top of it. I heard you need to get permission from Ports Authority beforehand. However, you are allowed to roam around the base of the lighthouse. The surrounding sea is very beautiful. If you have a drone, a good opportunity to get some good clicks!
lighthouse is a lighthouse but its not just a lighthouse. its a great place to clear the mind and just take nice landscape photographs üòä

We wanted to climb the lighthouse at the end of the day to admire the view but unfortunately the lighthouse is closed. They are building a fence so you're not able to go near it. Maybe have to pay entrance in the future. Even though the site is beautiful to spend some time

Devundara Light House is the name used by locals.  This is at the southernmost tip of Sri Lanka and close to one of the sacred places Sri Lankans visit to pray, i.e. the Devundara Devalaya. We were lucky to be able to climb to the top of the light house.  The view from the top is just breath taking.  On one side you see the shallow areas of the sea, where young men swim and fish and have fun the whole day.  One the other side, the deep Indian ocean that changes from blue to green.  It‚Äôs the perfect contrast from the sky and the surrounding area.  Beautiful Sri Lanka‚Ä¶.. nothing else! If you don‚Äôt get the opportunity to climb to the top of the light house, or if the climb is too much, the surrounding area is still beautiful and peaceful.  Sit in one of the outdoor benches and just absorb the beauty of this amazing landscape.

Please note that the Dondra Head Lighthouse is still closed after the scandal where guards requested entry fee from visitors on a public free entry location. Pass can be obtained via Colombo Harbour Principal but this does take some time. If you are still in Matara go to the small beach on the eastern side of the lighthouse for a clear view of this iconic building Rumours say it should open again in March 2017. Good luck

We climb to the top and the view was amazing. Really good place to visit if you visit Sri Lanka. But you will have to get a tuk there if you don't have a private vehicle. However the place is restricted now for everyone so you will need to get permission to enter premises and also have to get permission to go to the top of the lighthouse. The permission will be granted from sri lanka ports authority head office colombo.
Quaint lighthouse is located approximately 30 mins from Matara. It is a good walk from the bus stop but its totally worth it. Must visit at dusk

Nestled in a small village nearly 30 mins away from Matara, this is one of the most off beat place you can visit. The lighthouse cannot be accessed, but I have heard that locals do manage to get inside. Near the light house there is also a small beach that is littered with fishing boats, but there is enough space for a private picnic and a dip in the sea. The lighthouse comes alive just around dusk.
Mathara light house is situated location is lovely. It is nice in the evening time. But it's closed to public now.

Visited this place for a business purpose but still it's a must see place to all the Sri Lankans and of course the tourists as well. The  beach, the light house in the evenings and early in the mornings give such a refreshing feeling.

Unfortunately, we could not go upstairs because it seems that currently the access is somehow limited. Anyway, the view around is great. Not so easy to reach without tuk-tuk but one may try anyway. Very nice point to do some photo-shooting.

Quite a long walk from the bus station in Dondra to find the lighthouse CLOSED to the public. You can't even get close to the 'southernmost tip of Sri Lanka'. Small beach, busy with locals and no cafe/restaurant. Very disappointed.

Not only the lighthouse, but even the compound is currently off bound. At best you can spend time outside the walls, or go back a turn and spend time at the cove. Its a good place, esp during low tide on weekdays.

We stopped at the location at the insistence of our driver and dint regret it one bit.  It is one of the most beautifully located light houses I have seen.  On a sunny day it looked awesome with the blue-green sea as a back drop. There is a small cove next to it where you can have a dip. Do stop by for some lovely views.

It's a real nice place to be with a very beautiful environment. + you can have a nice sea bath over there, since there are plenty of spots to have a fun sea bath. Therefore don't forget to take some bathing stuff if you visit there. ( better to ask the local people about safer areas to bath also :-) )

It is a great adventure to visit the southernmost point of Sri Lanka, with knowing that there is nothing else but the ocean to the south.. Breathtaking view from the top of the Lighthouse, amazing surroundins with great beaches and possibilities of watersports.
Its worth visiting this place and have great views of the shore line. Light house is open to general public and can go till the top level for great views.
It is nice stop on the way from Mirissa to Galle, lighthouse is nice and area is clean, it would be 5 stars if we could go up.
We stopped in Dondra just because of this place and it worth. Nice clean place, the lighthouse among palm trees is so nice.

We went all the way to the lighthouse, only to be told that it is no longer open to the public because the locals charging the entrance fee did not work for the government, they were just making money for themselves. So since the 26th January 2016 the government found out about this and put a stop to it. If passing by its worth to take a look ,but don't go out your way

I enjoyed this place. This feeling when you know you are watching on the ocean and there might be nothing but water for hundred miles, no people only silence and ocean breath. This costs only 500 lkr and its worse it.

Dondra Head Lighthouse is a lighthouse located on Dondra Head near the southernmost point in Sri Lanka and is the tallest lighthouse in Sri Lanka and also one of the tallest in South East Asia. Dondra Head lighthouse is operated and maintained by the Sri Lanka Ports Authority. The lighthouse is near the village of Dondra, and is approximately 6 km (3.7 mi) southeast of Matara. The name Dondra is a synonym for "Devi-Nuwara" in the local Sinhala language, "Devi" meaning "Gods" and "Nuwara" meaning "City". Dondra is therefore derived to mean "City of the Gods".

This lighthouse is located on the southern most tip of the island. It is an operational lighthouse and is really well maintained, which includes the surrounding grassed gardens full of palm trees. It is a very peaceful setting. If you want to climb the lighthouse expect to pay a Rs500 fee. The views from the top are worth it. There is a long circular wrought iron staircase to navigate first but once there you have uninterrupted view for miles and miles up and down the coastline. If you are in the area definitely include it on your itinerary - it's one of the most scenic lighthouses in Sri Lanka.

It's so pathetic to see being Sri Lankan we have to take permission to enter. That's okay if same rule apply to all. But if a foreigner comes in they allow them in without any problem. For money. Feel so proud to be a Lankan. Lol.
Felt a bit ripped off to pay the fee imposed without any real ticket ...got a nice talk and view with the people working there and beautiful views from the top. Worth a visit.

This lighthouse is tucked away on the headland and not easily signed but well worth the effort to find. Worth paying the money to climb the internal spiral stairs and get out on the top for some stunning views of the bay below and all the coastline up and down from the lighthouse
Beautiful view from lighthouse but many stairs to get to the top also the charge is excessive. If you are visiting the lighthouse from the town take a tuk tuk as it is a long walk to get there.

The views from the top of the lighthouse are fully worth the pain you will feel the next day from climbing up the spiral staircase (sorry, wasn't counting the number of stairs, was too busy breathing!). The place is maintained very well by the navy, kept spotless and gardens well maintained. The curious thing this visit is when we arrived there, we were told that all Sri Lankans need to get permission from some naval HQ in Colombo, which we didn't know anything about. Although, foreigners were being allowed to enter the building. Fortunately, my partner was able to talk to the caretaker and we were allowed in. This incident was rather unfortunate considering as Sri Lankans we were restricted (well, almost) from visiting a famous landmark in our own country. We were told that locals tend to "mess things up" and that's why the rules were put in place. But considering there are navy personnel operating inside the lighthouse, I'm confused as to why strict discipline cannot be maintained. Surely a few CCTV cameras and a fine if you're caught vandalizing the place, will deter anyone from "messing up" such a charming landmark.

Please do not miss a visit out to the Dondra Head Lighthouse, wherever you may be staying on the south coast!  It is an amazingly beautiful, peaceful place, not visited by many. The most southern point of the island of Sri Lanka!  Maintained by the navy, as I understand it, visitors can climb to the top for spectacular views. The history is displayed in the foyer as you enter, plus the cartetaker can also answer your queries.  When the water below is especially clear, sharks can be seen swimming by!  This lighthouse was erected in the 1800's.  There are very clean (squat) toilets available, and a small boutique outside the front gates which offers drinks and tambli(coconut water).  A nominal donation is requested for entry to the lighthouse itself, though not to the grounds, of RS500. We did hear that a fee of RS1,000 may be charged from Jan. Very few visit this amazing site, which is a shame, though more pleasant for those who do, as it is extremely peaceful there!  Go see for yourself.
Green territory, walking varans, fascinating view from the top of the lighthouse. Totally must visit!

Lots of steep steps which seem like even more in the heat but totally worth it for the view from the walkway around the top. It is also possible to climb up even further in to the lantern room itself. Great for photo opportunities!

This is a well-kept lighthouse located in Dondra, surrounded by palm trees. For an entrance fee, you can climb the spiral staircase to the top of this lighthouse and enjoy a 360-degree view of the surrounding landscape. This is one of the southernmost spots in Sri Lanka: to the south, the only thing you will see is the Indian ocean, and the next land in this direction is Antarctica. If you have never been to a lighthouse before, this is a good one. Other than the views and the gardens, there is nothing else to see. Anyway, it's a nice spot for a quick stop if you are travelling around this area and would like to take some panoramic pictures.
Easy to visit from Matara and Polhena, by tuktuk. The view is superb. Take your camera! Walk around, get yourself informed about the history. Entrance fee is 500 rps pp

I like lighthouses‚ò∫Ô∏è and this one especially amazing cause is situated in Sri Lanka!:) beautiful view from lighthouse, nice nature around. But I think the entrance should be free of charge or at least less than 500 rip.!

It cost 500/p just to walk up the tower. It was a nice view but really nothing special. For them who photograph, the inside has epic lightning. But still not much to see all together. Though I have to admit the garden and tower was well taken care of.
Once you've climbed the entire lighthouse you can see a big part of the island. Wonderful view! Recommended for sure!

It's easy to see why this is the site of Sri Lanka's oldest lighthouse; it commands a majestic & strategic view of the Indian Ocean. Highly recommended for a fascinating visit, set amongst coconut palms & on the edge of huge waves crashing over a craggy outcrop, you can climb 200 steps to the top for a small donation. It's so worth the climb as views are breathtaking, although you might not be so impressed if you're scared of heights. It's fascinating to see how basic the original lighthouse was; they still have spare panes of 19th century glass in case of breakages in particularly violent weather & the old communication system from top to bottom is hilarious.

this is the south end of sir lanka and the SARRC ,you can have chance to go up there and see the south pole ,no one see that its far ,,,,,,,, so nice place and good chance to visit one of the oldest light house in the earth

We tried to go up and see the lighthouse; however, we were told that we need to get a harbor masters permission from Colombo! Also told teenage children not allowed; however we saw many tourists make their way up with kids even aged 10. We believe this is racism imposed by staff at the lighthouse - only towards locals. I hope the situation will change and more educated staff and systems implemented in the near future.

Beautifully kept  surroundings, interesting old workings, amazing views of the sea and land, good exercise after lying on mirissa beach, eating fish, and we saw whales on the radar half way up. Fee seemed to be discretionary.  Matara fort is like Galle before it was done up and then we stopped off at Polhena Beach on the way back.

It was an easy climb to this the highest lighthouse in Sri Lanka. Definitely worth a visit as the view from top is magnificent. Entrance fee paid to the guard is 500 rupees per person and obviously it goes directly to their pocket. If you have residence visa you can negotiate for a better deal.

220 steps each way, my wife counted. I was too busy working on my 'Uncontrolled Yogic Panting'. 360 degree views from the top make the climb worthwhile. Great photo opportunities both at the top and ground level. Dondra Heads was once the capital of the country and a significant Hindu port town. Prior to it's destruction by the invading Portuguese the town boasted over 1000 statues and temples covered with brass, copper and gold. The pillars of the largest temple are spread over the town and can be found by those looking for them, just ask any local as we did and they will point you in the right(ish) direction. It does take some looking for though.
It's actually just another light house. Nice to have seen it. It's in a really nice bay like place. Not to special. The scrounging is nice to have seen

The view from the top is great.  360 degree views from the most southern tip of Sri Lanka.  Lrp 500 per person paid to the lighthouse master.  The climb up takes you past each floor of the lighthouse with lots of original features still in place. the view from the top is amazing. Well worth the climb.

actually very worth to visit this place .and one of the main tourist attraction in southern sri lanka located at mathara. you can see nice sorounding area from the top of light house which has been build in british period .today also well preserved colonial architecture and some equipments are there.

If you are on South Coast of Sri Lanka, I recommend you to visit Dondra Lighthouse. You can get from Matara to Dondra by bus ‚Ññ32. You should get off on bus station near Buddha Temple, and walk 15 minutes to Lighthouse. The entrance fee is 500 Rs, we deal on 400 Rs per person. Easily get up on top and watch beautiful view. We were lucky to see the rainbow.
Wonderful views. The garden is beautiful. At the top you can see the ocean, the village, everything.

I loved the sight itself, small, nice park around the light house, you can rest in the heat. Beautiful view from up there, only walk if you manage steep stairs. The radar is on top, one level below the staff keeps monitoring, you can peep on their screen as you are moving upwards. They say that the light house is strong enough to withstand a tsunami, hopefully does not have to be tested...

The southernmost point of Sri Lanka is definitely worth visiting. It feels amazing to climb a 50 metres high snow-white lighthouse built by the English colonists in the 19th century and realise that in front of your eyes there is nothing but salty Indian Ocean and then ‚Äì the penguins of the Antarctica. All the building materials were delivered here from the UK by ships, so it‚Äôs like a little piece of England somewhere in topics. Not many tourists go there, so it‚Äôs quite laid back, almost empty, but not abandoned ‚Äì you can see all the equipment functioning, which is especially amusing. The view is breathtaking, the vibes are lovely, seems like nothing has changes since the colonist‚Äôs times, so it makes you feel a little bit like a colonist.

this is a nice and peaceful place - with a view over the blue ocean, knowing this is the most southern point on Sri Lanka and next stop down south is Antarctic the lighthouse is interesting and is looking fine, but the lighthouse itself is not the attraction - it is the area and the beautiful surroundings.

We met a really unpleasant person near the lighthouse's entrance who tried to charge 500 rs from each to get in. But he refused to give us any tickets. We didn't want our money to go right to his pocket. This corrupted system is awful. We were ready to pay these money to support poor people of Sri Lanka, but not this fat insolent guy. So we refused to get in. Really bad experience.
Worth a look is you are passing Dondra head! Drive down the little road passed the big temple and you will see small wooden sign posts directing you. Charmingly under advertised!

we walked from dondra bus station to this place. Its roughly 20 min and if you take the right street there are signs on the walk. Some locals will recognize you as a tourist and point you towards the lighthouse without asking ;). We didnt go up because you have a great view from below the palm trees to the south pole (well you dont see it ;)). They charge something for going up the lighthouse but we didn't opt for it. There is a small shop right at the entrance where you can have a coconut for refreshment for 50 rp. The rocky beach looks great and we brought some food with us and enjoyed the place and the view.

If you are traveling the Southern coast of Sri Lanka, you should not give it a miss. Entrance to the ground is free but you need to pay Rs500/pax to get to the top of the lighthouse. The climb is steep so really not suitable for very young kids. The view from the ground and top are magnificent.
Great view from the lighthouse, we payed some rupies but not sure we had to, any way its a nice spot to stop at.

It was a nice lighthouse with great views but we were charged $500 per person to visit (plus we were charged for our driver) and yet there were no posted signs regarding tickets and no tickets.  I suspect we were scammed but as this was the only time in a three week trip I am not going to get upset about it but go prepared
not many places would let the public up in a working lighthouse never mind out round the top, but that's what you can do here and after 200 steps what a view once you get there

This is an amazing place to get breath-taking photos if you are a photographer. We had to bribe the guy who administer this colonial tower, since it's not opened for visitors (according to the same dude) however Rs. 400/- or 500/- would suffice for one person. The key thing here is to negotiate!! i don't know the effects of standing next to a radar but keep that hazard in mind. i haven't seen how the maritime radar function, until i went there, but you are not going to get any education on how it works, since you gonna walk pass it to the top.

Please avoid going up the tower! Right on top of the viewpoint there is a Martine radar! This is a big health risk because it transmits a lot of radiation. You should never stand close to a radarstation. Radar is like a microwave, stand that close and do the math.... Directly when i came down in told the supervisor the risk that are involded. The reaction i got was that they had people going up there very often and had no illnes. Avoid going up!
Dondra is not a main city in Sri Lanka. Please add this place under Matara Category.Less than 10 Km Between Matara City and Dondra.

Dondra Lighthouse is a pleasant hour's drive S of Galle along the coast road.  You can go up to the top of the light and walk around outside for great views of the seas.  Some other reviewers mention in passing that it's neat the southernmost point in Sri Lanka.  However, all the other reviews on TA don't mention the #1 reason I went to see it,  So to speak, they may have missed the point. Just as arbitrary lines on maps mark the borders of countries, other lines on charts mark the arbitrary boundaries of seas.  The southernmost point of Dondra marks exactly where major seas come together.  The ocean rolls on heedless of the boundaries, just as the Alps themselves don't care whether we call them Swiss, French or Italian; but the borders are quite official.  The IHO, the International Hydrographic Organization, agrees on the lines, and they agreed the three major bodies of water meet at a single point, "the Southern extreme of Dondra Point.  If stand at this point and look due south, you're looking at the Indian Ocean.  But from the same point headed west, you see the Laccadive Sea.  And from the same point an imaginary line running East by South marks the Southern boundary of the Bay of Bengal. Technically you can jump into the Bay of Bengal, swim across the Indian Ocean all the way to the Laccadive Sea and swim back again in under five minutes.  Better be a good swimmer though, depending on the conditions.  Today there were heavy waves coming in from the west, and quite a strong current running from west to east; it was like swimming in a river.  Rip tides are a real danger in Sri Lanka; if in doubt, better to err on the side of caution. Naturally, all three bodies of water can be seen from the top of the lighthouse.  I will try to attach two pix.  The first was taken looking NW; the water in the foreground is officially the Bay of Bengal, while the water on the far side of the point is the Laccadive Sea.  The second pic shows the point itself, where all three meet.

We wanted to go to the south most point of Sri Lanka and visited the Dondra Lighthouse, At the time we arrived, there were few foreigners at the top of the lighthouse taking photos. When we asked to go up there, the caretakers told us we have to obtain a permission from Colombo to go up there. I was laughing to myself. What an idiotic system is that. They better bring that person right down to Dondra to give permission to visitors.

The lighthouse is located in a well maintained complex. you can request the care taker to allow you to go to the top by climbing the steps. You have to pay him Rs 500 (we were two persons). The light house complex is very well maintained as is the lighthouse itself. The climb to the top is not strenuous at all the views and the breeze at the top of the lighthouse are great. You can stay at the top for as long as you want.
Unforgettable! Worth the climb and 400 Rp/person bribe to the lighthouse officer... We stayed 1,5 hours on top.

We arrived at the Dondra Lighthouse just before sunset, paid our Rupees 500 each and then climbed the 200 steps up to the top. I was well worth the climb and although the sunset was disappointing we felt it was worth the money too
You need to climb more than ten floors, and you need to pay for the climb. But the view of the top is definitely worth it.

Visitors to the Dondra lighthouse will experience being at the most southerly tip of the island with only ocean between them and the Antarctic. The tall lighthouse is open to visitors for a fee and from the top one has the spectacular views of both ocean and land. For those who dislike heights, Dondra is still a special place with a rocky shore where one can enjoy views of the sea and local fishing activities. July/August is the usual time of the Dondra perahera when the place becomes exceedingly busy.

This is located on Dondra Head near the southernmost point in Sri Lanka and is the tallest lighthouse in the country.Lighthouse is operated and maintained by the Sri Lanka Ports Authority. You have to get permission(from Sri Lanka Ports Authority)to climb to the top.

Don't miss a trip out  here. The last landfall before Antartica . Very peaceful, pristinely maintained. We didn't take up the offer to climb up inside the lighthouse but it is a great place for a picnic with a pretty place to swim.

This is considered to be one of the tallest in Asia. A giagantic structure where you feel so small standing next to it and thats an awesome experience. There is a spiral stairecase that takes you up to the top and it gives an amazing feeling walking inside it. Each floor contains a room and some are even suitable for a bedroom. The top is windy and you see all around the place partly the sea and partly land. Looking down can make a person scared of height freek out. The lamp board on top is huge and should be brilliant at night. This is certainly an experienec one should not miss.

paid Rps250 (locals only Rps10!!) to see ... nothing. December is not the season to visit this nature specialty; locals told us that the umami is on its best in july/august. Really, the rock itself is not worth visiting. There are much nicer places at the different beaches. When you want to see the rock itself, please, by preference, go to a good whale spotting boat company. When you go off shore, you get a much better impression from dondra head including the lighthouse saving Rps 250 per person on the trip.

Dondra lighthouse is the southern point of Sri Lanka. When I get on the top of the lighthouse I saw an amazing views - u see the Indian Ocean so far, a very high waves, people like a little ants ) U must visit this lighthouse, u ll never feel sorry for that!
